Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Knowledge and Building the Research Infrastructure in Education and STEM Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues the work of the AERA Grants Program, which provides competitive research grants to both doctoral students and education research scientists who conduct secondary analyses of large-scale national and international data sets from the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES). The project also will carry out two new strands of work: (1) through a partnership with the National Center for Analysis of Longitudinal Data in Education Research, managed by the Urban Institute, the project enables access to and use of state longitudinal data bases for scientific research on student learning, performance, and achievement in STEM; and (2) a programmatic component to foster secondary analysis of data emerging from NSF-funded investigator-initiated STEM projects that have opportunities for further discovery will be explored.

The AERA Grants Program seeks to increase the capacity of the STEM education field to conduct high quality research using large-scale data sets through its grants, the findings from workshops, and the publications resulting from "think tank" activities that explore critical issues in STEM education research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Grants Program of the American Educational Research Association (AERA) is a longstanding initiative (since the early 1990s) dedicated to building the capacity of research scientists to advance knowledge about STEM education and learning. The program is primarily directed to researchers using quantitative methods to analyze large-scale data sets sponsored by the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) and the National Science Foundation (NSF). Also, under this award (DRL 0941014), the program expanded its focus (a) to maximize the use of data from NSF-funded projects and (b) to foster the use of administrative data by the research community. The current grant commenced on November 1, 2009, and ended on October 31, 2016. Funding for the current grant was approximately $4 million dollars. 

The vast majority of this NSF award (almost 70%) supported the core research and training components of the program. The Grants Program accomplishes its goals primarily through research grants to doctoral students for dissertation research and to early career scholars. Dissertation Grants were $20,000 each; Research Grants were in the range of $20,000 to $35,000 for 1 to 2 years.  

The Grants Program also provided opportunities for training and professional development through the AERA Institutes on Statistical Analysis for Education Policy, the Faculty Institutes for the Teaching of Statistics with Large-Scale Data Sets, and special sessions at the AERA annual meetings. The Institutes on Statistical Analysis for Education Policy, for example, consisted of intensive sessions lasting several days to provide hands-on training in use of the NSF and NCES data sets to examine topics in education research. The topics included the use of large-scale data to study mathematics education and outcomes, causal inference using international data, and the transition from high school to postsecondary education. Over the seven years of the project, nearly 300 researchers and faculty members participated in these Institutes.

The selection of candidates for these program initiatives was administered by AERA through a competitive peer-review process guided by a Governing Board consisting of senior scholars widely recognized for their substantive and methodological expertise. The Governing Board also actively participated in two research conferences each year designed for awardees, and directed or served as faculty for the Institutes.

The Grants Program is known across the education research community and related fields of science for excellence in capacity building and for contributing knowledge related to education and learning, particularly related to STEM. Over the seven years of this award, the dissertation and research awardees were selected competitively from a talented pool of 1160 applicants. Of the 148 awards, 77 dissertation awards were conferred from 590 applicants (13 percent), and 71 research awards were conferred from 570 applicants (12 percent). The program has a strong track record of supporting a diverse pool of researchers and encouraging scholars early in their careers. Of the 148 awardees, 96 (65 percent) were women and 53 (36 percent) were from underrepresented racial/ethnic groups.

The AERA Grants Program also took the lead (well before recent federal policies) to foster a culture of data sharing with NSF-funded studies in STEM education and learning. Under the current award, AERA and the Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) launched a cooperative data sharing initiative in 2011 to encourage researchers to archive and share their research data at ICPSR after completion of projects. Activities included a workshop for prospective awardees with large-scale data sets, a dedicated AERA-ICPSR data sharing website, symposia at the AERA Annual Meeting on data sharing, and technical assistance to NSF investigators. To date, 10 projects are archived under this arrangement, thus making available a rich source of data for further analyses.

The Grants Program has also undertaken initiatives aimed at expanding access to and use of state longitudinal data bases for scientific research. Most recently, in December 2015, AERA and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), Centre for Educational Research and Innovation (CERI), held a joint conference aimed at developing consensus guidelines on the quality of and access to longitudinal administrative systems in education. Two symposia have been held at AERA Annual Meetings on this topic and draft model guidelines for data producers and users are under consideration.

The Grants Program reflects a commitment on the part of AERA and the National Science Foundation to produce rigorous and robust knowledge related to STEM education and learning from early education through the workforce, to ensure a next generation of quality scientists capable of doing such work, and to anticipate how the scientific community can share their assets and new forms of big data responsibly to advance knowledge and provide education of quality to all students.
